articles.headline: California Dream Under Attack in All Manner of Cinematic Imaginings
articles.snippet: The disaster film “San Andreas” is the latest example of Hollywood’s tendency to revel in California’s pain, but it comes at a worrisome moment for the state.
articles.abstract: The disaster film “San Andreas” is the latest example of Hollywood’s tendency to revel in California’s pain, but it comes at a worrisome moment for the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Here it comes again: The California Apocalypse.

articles.headline: Charter Deal for Time Warner Cable Signals Shift in TV Industry
articles.snippet: Charter is expected to announce on Tuesday a $55 billion deal for its larger rival and an approximately $10 billion takeover of a smaller competitor, Bright House Networks.
articles.abstract: Charter is expected to announce on Tuesday a $55 billion deal for its larger rival and an approximately $10 billion takeover of a smaller competitor, Bright House Networks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Trying to succeed where Comcast failed, Charter Communications has struck a deal to buy Time Warner Cable, an acquisition that would create a powerhouse in the consolidating American cable and broadband industry.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Cleveland Reaches Settlement With Justice Department Over Police Conduct
articles.snippet: Federal authorities had cited a pattern of unconstitutional policing and excessive use of force in a report on the Cleveland Division of Police.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities had cited a pattern of unconstitutional policing and excessive use of force in a report on the Cleveland Division of Police.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Cleveland has reached a settlement with the Justice Department over what federal authorities said was a pattern of unconstitutional policing and excessive use of force, people briefed on the case said Monday.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Matt Apuzzo

articles.headline: With Money Drying Up, Greece Is All but Bankrupt
articles.snippet: The government’s call to conserve funds has been far-reaching, with cities sending any surplus cash to Athens, while hospitals and schools face strict orders not to hire people.
articles.abstract: The government’s call to conserve funds has been far-reaching, with cities sending any surplus cash to Athens, while hospitals and schools face strict orders not to hire people.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Bulldozers lie abandoned on city streets. Exhausted surgeons operate through the night. And the wealthy bail out broke police departments.

articles.headline: One-Time Bonuses and Perks Muscle Out Pay Raises for Workers
articles.snippet: Employees are steadily missing out on annual salary increases that compound over time, as companies exercise financial control by opting for one-off bonuses and other rewards.
articles.abstract: Employees are steadily missing out on annual salary increases that compound over time, as companies exercise financial control by opting for one-off bonuses and other rewards.
articles.lead_paragraph: Yacht-size bonuses for Wall Street big shots and employee-of-the-month plaques for supermarket standouts are nothing new, but companies’ continued efforts to keep costs down have pushed employers to increasingly turn to one-off bonuses and nonmonetary rewards at the expense of annual pay raises.

articles.headline: As Facebook Sweeps Across Europe, Regulators Gird for Battle
articles.snippet: The European Court of Justice is expected to issue a preliminary decision over whether the social network giant can continue transferring data between Europe and the United States.
articles.abstract: The European Court of Justice is expected to issue a preliminary decision over whether the social network giant can continue transferring data between Europe and the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — One arm of the European Union is looking into whether Facebook and other tech companies unfairly favor their own services over those of rivals. At least five data protection watchdogs across the region are questioning Facebook’s privacy settings.

articles.headline: Four Words That Imperil Health Care Law Were All a Mistake, Writers Now Say
articles.snippet: Democrats and Republicans say a clause affecting subsidies, now before the Supreme Court, was an inadvertent product of a sloppy merging of versions.
articles.abstract: Democrats and Republicans say a clause affecting subsidies, now before the Supreme Court, was an inadvertent product of a sloppy merging of versions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They are only four words in a 900-page law: “established by the state.”

articles.headline: In Time Warner Cable Deal, Charter Seeks National Heft
articles.snippet: Charter Communications’ $55 billion bid for Time Warner Cable is aimed at helping fulfill Charter’s long-held strategy to become a legitimate national player in the industry.
articles.abstract: Charter Communications’ $55 billion bid for Time Warner Cable is aimed at helping fulfill Charter’s long-held strategy to become a legitimate national player in the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was only 15 months ago that Charter Communications looked like a big loser in the race to add heft in the cable and broadband industry. Comcast, a rival, had swooped in with an audacious $45 billion bid for Time Warner Cable, appearing to end the prolonged takeover battle that Charter had been waging for the cable operator.

articles.headline: Broadband at the Center of Charter-Time Warner Cable Deal
articles.snippet: The $56.7 billion offer is the latest in the sector as companies struggle to keep pace with the changing habits of how Americans watch and pay for television.
articles.abstract: The $56.7 billion offer is the latest in the sector as companies struggle to keep pace with the changing habits of how Americans watch and pay for television.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Charter Communications announced a pair of deals on Tuesday to acquire Time Warner Cable and Bright House Networks for a total of $67.1 billion, it put the focus squarely on the cable industry’s future: broadband.

articles.headline: French Muslims Say Veil Bans Give Cover to Bias
articles.snippet: The head coverings of observant Muslim women have become one of the most potent flash points in the nation’s tense relations with its Muslim population.
articles.abstract: The head coverings of observant Muslim women have become one of the most potent flash points in the nation’s tense relations with its Muslim population.
articles.lead_paragraph: WISSOUS, France — Malek Layouni was not thinking about her Muslim faith, or her head scarf, as she took her excited 9-year-old son to an amusement site near Paris. But, as it turned out, it was all that mattered.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Alissa J. Rubin
